A single simplified example suffices for God's sake. You don't need to explain every single aspect of optical illusions to me just to make a point about how the brain unifies the pictures from the two eyes. Which is in turn just to illustrate something about the mind.Also in chapter 1 he goes into very long details about how a robot perceives it's surroundings and stuff like that.In chapters 2 and 3 he goes to LENGTHS to justify his view about human nature, and also explain how natural selection works and how everything else is wrong. I AM NOT READING THIS BOOK TO LEARN ABOUT NATURAL SELECTION! Just get to the point. He goes on and on to prove why this school of psychology or that view about evolution is wrong. This constitutes most of chapters 2 and 3. Being bad at explaining thingsAnd after all these, when he actually tries to explain something about "how the mind works", he fails. I cannot understand what he is saying.I have had the pleasure of reading The Fabric Of The Cosmos by Brian Greene. He explains things magically. The Selfish Gene is also an amazing book. I knew a lot about physics and evolution after reading those books. And they also don't dumb it down too much.But when reading this book I feel like I'm reading an unknown language.The unrelated parts about how robots see or how 3D movies work are easy to grasp. But when he gets to the real thing he really sucks. Maybe that's why he keeps going on and on about unrelated things.PS: This is my review after I read this book for the first time more than a year ago. After reading 3 more chapters than the first time it's now obvious to me that it's not me, it's Pinker:Does this book even have an editor? It looks like Pinker has written all of it in one sitting, not having a picture in mind or looking back to realize how off-topic he is going. He is explaining something and in doing so he goes to explain something else and something else and so on. This book has no structure. Not to mention all the unnecessarily long explanations of details.Left reading it because couldn't learn anything from it.
I presume psychology students read this since I'm writing about him in my next book. This is pioneering philosophy.
Pinker is a true scholar and incisive mind (no pun intended). Not an breezy, easy read but intelligent, interesting and clearly stated. His body of work is a real gem.

Pinker’s book How The Mind Works is a very interesting book for those people who are interested in the science of the mind, like psychology or neuroscience. The only thing I could say was a downfall is how long the book is; reading this book took a lot of time but other than that I would totally recommend it. This book makes you think; why do memories fade? What makes us laugh? Why do fools fall in love? Why do we need robots when we are the actual living things that have the ability to read? The brain is such an important organ in our body and according to Pinker we don’t give it enough credit. He explains a lot of about our minds, and how common sense is not common. Confusing? Not really because common sense is different in every person so really its not common. He explains what the mind is and how the brain is not the mind, how it evolved, how it allows us to see, think, feel, and ponder the mysteries of life, between other things. He wrote, “The mind is a system of organs of computation, designed by natural selection to solve the kinds of problems our ancestors faced in their foraging way of life, in particular, understanding and outmaneuvering objects, animals, plants, and other people” (p. 21). And he compared the human mind with machine computation to show how humans can design a computer to appear to be thinking, when it fact is it not. One of the most interesting topics was the genetics it also talked about, for example, the parent/child conflict, sibling rivalry, and the development of personality. It was an interesting part because it focuses on the genetic of the child. So two twins that were brought up separately would have a similar personality, while two adopted children brought up in the same household would not share a common trend, and are as similar to each other, as two random children pick from a list. And also the computational theory of the mind that allows us to keep beliefs and desires in our explanations of behavior while planting them squarely in the physical universe. Basically, Pinker says that the computational view of the mind means that consciousness - the ability of the mind that experiences stimuli and thought- has no apparent function. That people could go through the some sort of mental activity without experiencing any of it. He says there is no way to prove that the person sitting next to you is not a "philosophical zombie," who acts like they think and feel but is really just a mechanical thing. Now ask yourself, am I real? Is your teacher, your pet, your friend real? I learned that without the computational theory, it is impossible to make sense of the evolution of the mind. And that even though Pinker tries to explain as best as he can how the mind works, no one really knows.Overall, I found this book to be very interesting, I even learned that President Reagan was shot because John Hinckley, the shooter, wanted to impress a girl! I don’t regret reading it since I would like to study neuroscience in the future and this has certainly helped understanding the brain and how it works. I definitely recommend it if you are willing to devote your time to learning and understanding a little bit better how the human mind works.

When it comes to non-fiction, I'm always on the lookout for the next Big Picture Book -- a book with a simple thesis that possesses startling explanatory power into how the world works. For modern economics and culture, there's Naomi Klein's No Logo: No Space, No Choice, No Jobs. For world history and ethnography, there's Jared Diamond's Guns, Germs and Steel. For the human brain, there's this book.Pinker's thesis is very simply stated: the human brain is an organ designed by natural selection to equip our ancestors to survive and reproduce in a very specific environment, and is therefore adapted to particular tasks. For brain functions as diverse as image processing, language, and abstract thought, Pinker lays out a very compelling reverse-engineering argument as to how these capabilities must have been selected for among our primate ancestors. His basic goal is to establish a clear-cut case that a "human nature" exists, and to describe how it was sculpted by natural selection. This idea is incredibly offensive to a large part of academia, who embrace the "blank slate" model of human behavior, and so Pinker spends quite a lot of time preemptively defending his thesis from these critics.One of his most interesting chapters involves what he calls the "cognitive niche," the evolutionary space that allows a large problem-solving organ like the brain (which uses an incredible amount of our bodies' calories) to be a positive adaptation. Pinker makes a strong case that the kind of general-purpose intelligence that we possess is anything but inevitable in an evolutionary process -- after all, it has only evolved once so far. It might seem a prosaic insight, but it flies in the face of a thousand years of thought, including most post-Darwinian theorizing, that touts such metaphors as the "great chain of being" and the "evolutionary ladder." Rather, our intelligence came to be (and could only have come to be) in very particular circumstances, after a number of prerequisites had been fulfilled -- including good stereoscopic vision, social living, hands, and hunting.The book's main flaw is that Pinker doesn't seem to understand who his audience is. Passages alternate between pedantically technical and ploddingly simple, as if he's writing for a layman one minute and a biologist the next. This gets especially bad during his bizarre, lengthy defense of natural selection as the agent of evolution, as well as when he's explaining neural networks. Frustratingly, these long, dense passages only exist to show that the status quo is wrong in some subtle respect that he never fully enunciates.All in all, though, this book is an excellent introduction to evolutionary psychology, and shouldn't be missed.

I first read this after it came out about 15 years ago and was already becoming a big fan of Pinker. Reading it again now, I see that I'd forgotten much about his forceful defense of evolutionary psychology - probably because it was only a few years ago that I recognized that it needed defending. It's such a powerful explanatory tool that there is clearly some truth to it, regardless of the exact details about the mind's modularity. So at the time I read this, it was a fascinating introduction to what I assumed would be the accepted state of the art of scientific thought in this area. Now, with critics bashing EP for reasons as much about political correctness as they are about rigorous science, it's worth re-reading Pinker's clear and confident assurances of its validity.There is extensive discussion of and reliance on the knowledge of evolution in general, which of course is exactly how it must be - to understand why a body part looks or behaves the way it does, it has to be viewed in light of the process that it resulted from. The mind is not exempt from natural selection, and it's strange that many people who know better claim that it should be. While the basics of evolution may be already familiar to readers from other sources, and some of the material, such as the list of hominid ancestors, may have become outdated in recent years, Pinker's writing is so good that it's nevertheless a pleasure to read.He also managed to brilliantly shut down the free will debate back when I was obviously still fuzzy on it (since I later went on to read Dennett's overly complicated attempts at justifying claims of its existence) on p. 55: "...ethical theory requires idealizations like free, sentient, rational, equivalent agents whose behavior is uncaused, and its conclusions can be sound and useful even though the world, as seen by science, does not really have uncaused events". Seems like I would have gotten the point if I'd been paying better attention!There are numerous other surprisingly clear explanations of initially mysterious phenomena, from stereo vision to emotion to categorization. On the other hand, some of the explanations do seem a bit overly laborious now, either because some of what he explains really has become accepted and now goes without saying, or maybe just because the computation related explanations are common knowledge among software professionals. But you have to admire the well-structured way that the reader is led through the arguments to their logical conclusions.Bottom line: as bluntly audacious as the book's title may seem, Pinker actually does achieve his goal. The explanation in this book really is, to the best of our knowledge, how the mind works.

The beginning sections of this book on consciousness, visual perception, cognitive structure, and how the structure of language can illuminate the way that the brain actually processes information are excellent, and worth the price of the book right there. In particular, I don't think you will find many more interesting discussions on how seeing works than Pinker's description of why so many people are frustrated by Magic Eye diagrams (personally, I've always despised them, and now I know why!). As a hardcore work on intelligence those parts don't reach the heights of Marvin Minsky's godlike book The Society of Mind, as few books by mortals can ever hope to, but they're still quite good. The later sections of the book, however, are much less focused and seem to be more about social structure - i.e. the interaction of many minds - than about the mind, per se. I suppose they're justified because most if not all social behavior can be explained as epiphenomena of the way that our brains are wired, and he did find ways to ground things like incest taboos to the evolutionary explanations he brought up in the first few parts, yet I kept wishing he would go back to talking about all of the neat things psychologists have learned about how to fool our systems of perception and what that says about the brain rather than snarking about academic debates over gender roles. As a side note, I can't help but think that Pinker must have been a huge hippie back in the 60s and 70s, and is working out some issues with that part of his life in his works. The Family Values chapter in particular is rife with a peculiar mix of open contempt for the peace-and-love sentiments of stuff like John Lennon's Imagine, along with heavily qualified semi-assurances that the stifling conservative cynicism that John Lennon was opposing is equally misguided and not supported by any natural or biological laws. Pinker never contradicts himself, exactly, you just definitely get the impression that maybe he had recently found some pictures of himself in bell-bottoms or something and is trying to exorcise some bad memories through popular science non-fiction by taking a "the answer is in the middle!" half-stance. It definitely doesn't have the same sense of scientific rigor that the first half of the book did, anyway. Thankfully he expanded the better parts about the history of violence into his recent excellent book The Better Angels of Our Nature (which still has some questionable hippie-bashing, yet is still a cohesive work on its own). Overall I would recommend to inhale everything up to the Hotheads chapter, and then afterwards try to keep an eye out for buried gems like his discussion of the brain's mysterious relationship to music, which is a nice complement to full-length books like Daniel Levitin's The World In Six Songs. Overall quite good.

This book is a keeper- thought provoking and informative about how language ability develops from an innate instinct in homosapiens. Pinker debunks evolutionary theories such as by disproving whether chimpanzees communicate as humans do through universal language. I particularly enjoyed the discussions about Sign Language and spoken language that illustrates how the use of signs is a grammar of its own developed as spoken language and as meaningful. Pinker is a student of Chomsky but separates from his theories of transformational generative grammar in several ways.His arguments are easy to follow throughout and I highly recommend it to those like myself who have questioned how all languages evolved from one language into many dialects across the world. It is fascinating to discover that universal language grammar underlies all languages.

Steven Pinker, director of the Center for Cognitive Neuroscience at MIT, argues that the mind is a computational computer. He uses Darwin's concept of reverse engineering to show how most of man's mental and emotional traits evolved.Pinker also shows how the mind was designed by natural selection to solve the kinds of problems our ancestors faced in their hunter/gatherer existence, which may be why we have such trouble explaining such esoteric concepts as consciousness and sentience.Pinker does not have a whole lot of respect for Freud, B.F. Skinner, or the Standard Social Science Model, which views the mind as a blank slate at birth. He disdains a moral approach when discussing natural selection, which gets him in trouble with feminists among other value-laden "isms". Instead, he argues for a "module-packed mind" that "allows both for innate motives that lead to evil acts and for innate motives that can avert them."When discussing the computational mind, Pinker spends a lot of time on the eye. He shows how the eye evolved from light sensitive skin tissue, how humans developed stereoscopic vision leading to a bigger brain, how the brain tricks us into believing that matter is solid, and how seeing in color and in three dimensions led to more brain capacity. Pinker even shows us how the "Mind's eye" works. The eye connects to the brain, but the brain also connects to the eye.Emotions began with the family and extended to non-family because foragers lived in groups. We love people who carry our genes. Pinker shows how the emotions evolve from the family to non-family relationships using reciprocal altruism. If you grant a favor to another (such as supplying him with meat) and he later returns the favor, you like him. If he cares for you when you are sick with no apparent compensation, you grow to love him. Cheaters inspire other emotions such as anger and resentment and the list grows. Guilt happens when we're cheating and we know it. Sympathy is an emotion for gaining gratitude. Body language ensures that emotions are hard to fake. Most people have scam detectors; you can tell the difference between a real smile and that of a beauty contestant.Pinker also discusses bi-products of natural selection such as religion, music, philosophy and art. As mentioned earlier, we are blessed (or cursed) with a forager's brain. "The intellect evolved to crack the defense of things in the natural and social world," not answer such questions as "Why do bad things happen to good people?" We are lucky our stone-age minds do as well as they do when tackling complex scientific problems.

I know this book exist back in 2008. I bought a copy in 2012, and I finally finished reading it with the help of audible book in 2017. I enjoyed reading his witty arguments. " The direct pursuit of happiness is a recipe for an unhappy life. "

In writing this book, Pinker does for the mind what Maxwell did for electromagnetism; he assumes axioms, he derives propositions and he submits them to empirical tests. The axioms are physicalism and the tenets of evolution, that is, the mind is the product of the brain and the brain is --as every other trait of the human body-- an organ designed by evolution. The propositions are assertions about the senses, perception, abstract thought, human psychology, consciousness, personal relationships, ethics and so on. The empirical tests are findings reported in books and papers published in the fields of cognitive science, evolutionary psychology and similar.This is such a unique approach to the human condition, that the book would be invaluable even if the endeavour failed. It is hard to imagine what an explanation of the mind would look like, yet this book provides a bold, wide and exclusively scientific prototype. It is surprising how many issues about human psyche can be illuminated just by framing the questions as evolutionary 'objectives': "how does trait X help people survive and reproduce in a pre-modern society"? By asking questions in that way again and again, Pinker frees himself from irrelevant stuff (like political correctness, historical contingencies, etc) and allows us to focus on the problem at hand. The shift in attitude compared to classic psychology, with its emphasis on subconsciously repressed thoughts accompanied by myriads of ad hoc syndromes, is drastic.Even more stunning is the fact that the book delivers; all that elegance and simplicity does actually get the job done. The explanations offered are crisp, the deductions are easy-to-follow, the nature of the phenomena seems finally uncovered. There are no appeals to obscure ideas, there are no apparent problems from which the author hides away and there is scarcly any proposition that is not also borne out with experimental data. In nutshell, the book reads (and feels) like a cognitive tour-de-force, a hallmark of evolutionary reasoning applied to the most perplexing component of our biological design.I enjoyed both the axiomatic approach as well its success, and reaped a lot of methodological and factual insights. I fully recommend it to everyone that is eager to investigate the implications of evolutionary theory on human condition, as well as to anyone who feels unsatisfied with the current exegesis of how Homo Sapiens came to be.

There have been hundreds of reader reviews of HOW THE MIND WORKS, published way back in 1997. What I have to say won't add much to the discussion. Nevertheless, here we go! Considering Steven Pinker's arguments in HOW THE MIND WORKS and beginning to comprehend the author's thought processes have certainly been interesting and rewarding challenges. The book got me thinking and challenged me in many new directions. I would recommend this book on these bases alone!Having said that, I may have discerned more plausible (albeit indirect) claims to truth arising from the fictitious novels of Charles Dickens, which I happen to be reading and re-reading over this same one-year time period (Yes, I've been digesting Pinker SLOWLY!). Dickens doesn't actually "prove" any of his inferences about the human condition, but then again Pinker's so-called "reverse-engineering" of the mind according to the principles of evolutionary and behavioral psychology does not really do much of that either.Both a strength as well as a possible weakness of this author is his ability to think out loud in ways which the average reader understands. He is brilliant. However, this results in a book which is unnecessarily lengthy (673 pages for the print version-- I plodded through EVERY page) and at times more than a little self-congratulatory. Though rather humble compared to some of the authors he likes to quote, Pinker sometimes can be found in these pages to be preaching to his choir. He at times sets up straw men, and takes unjustified cheap shots at those with whom he disagrees. His casual treatment of a few religious texts is unprofessional for a supposed scientist. What makes these occasional unsupported cheap shots more abhorring is that he rarely supports his own arguments with actual substantiated data. Though extremely interesting and a window on the direction of future scientific discovery, there seems to be lack of solid evidence and support for many of the enticing (and seemingly in line with common sense) ideas about love, family, taking care of siblings-- even the basic assertation that the mind is a computational machine. Other ideas are just old rehashes. In conclusion, however, let me reiterate that this is still a book which will challenge your thinking. Keep working through it.

Pinker aptly summarizes his book somewhere in the last chapter thus: "The mind is a neural computer, fitted by natural selection with combinatorial algorithms for casual and probabilistic reasoning about plants, animals, objects, and people. It is driven by goal states that served biological fitness in ancestral environments, such as food, sex, safety, parenthood, friendship, status, and knowledge."To expand on that a just a bit: through the eight long chapters of the book Pinker tries to cover major systems of the human brain (visual, memory, logic, deduction, etc.) and brain-related human characteristics (social behavior, emotions, art), considering specifically their "adaptive design" -- that is, how such a thing could have come to exist as we know them now through eons of natural selection. Throughout he leans heavily on the ideas proffered by John Tooby and Leda Cosmides, who invited him to spend a year with them at the Center for Evolutionary Psychology at UC Santa Barbara, spawning this book. (He argues the fitness of their theories quite well, perhaps increasing their chances of survival, if you will.)Conspicuously absent from the many facets discussed is that of language -- but of course he has more than thoroughly covered that subject in his earlier book, "The Language Instinct". If you are at all interested in languages and linguistics, I'd highly recommend that read.Alas, while Pinker does make comparisons with various models of machine learning which try to emulate some portion of the mind's reasoning ability, he is hardly able to explain the "how"of "how the mind works," as the title might lead you to believe -- perhaps in part because we understand so little about as of yet. But in accepting the task of laying out so much of what we do understand of the mind's functions -- and explaining them in such a way that the reader does not require expertise in cognitive science, psychology, and biology -- Pinker has given us curious readers quite a gift.

Metaphorically speaking, this work starts with much hemming and hawing. It's clear that Steven Pinker has written, taught, and spoken about the subject of the human mind before, and that he's had his share of run-ins with people who strongly disagree with his view on the matter.Much effort is spent refuting hypothetical nay-sayers; Freudian psychologists, religious authorities, politically correct activists, prejudiced people, and so on. Pinker's agenda is to be as scientific as possible, which means attempting to explain the human mind by forces of nature and biology.As a scientifically inclined, atheist reader who's already read Dawkin's popular introduction to the subject of evolution (The Selfish Gene), I found the first couple of hundred pages hard to come through. All that pre-emptive defence against counter-arguments runs in open doors with me; it only gets repetitive.It didn't help that the language required my entire attention. In some sense, I think the book is well-written; it uses helpful analogies and metaphors, it's satisfactorily technical when it needs to convince me, and sprinkled (sparsely) throughout the text is a sophisticated, although dry, wit. In another sense, the language is sometimes hard to decipher, and I had to read many sentences twice or thrice before I could pick up the meaning.It does get better once it gets going, though. The chapters on relationships and sexuality were both insightful and compelling, so I'm happy that I kept reading.In all, I think this was a tour de force of a work. As always, I write my review immediately after completion, while I'll only know how much I got out of the book when the dust has settled. I think, however, that I learned a thing or two. Still, it was a long book, and, for long stretches, a dry reading experience.

How the Mind Works is an effort by a cognitive scientist/linguist to explain how the mind - consciousness/sentience/whatever you want to call it - arose and how it functions. The first few chapters covered material I already knew and thus moved slowly, but once we got into material I wasn't familiar with, the book was pretty interesting. There were a few places where the author's own biases were on display, but that's true of all of us.The book is twenty years old, so it's out of date with current research, but I don't think that would impede the enjoyment of the casual reader. I'd recommend it if you are interested in the subject (with the caveat that I have not looked to see what else is available on this subject that is more recent - I was actually looking for a different title by this author at my library and picked up this book in its stead).
Another epic masterpiece from the master of making the advancements of scientific knowledge approachable.

This was not an easy read and I was glad to be finished at last.The content was fairly interesting. I don't agree with his strong leanings towards Evolutionary Psychology in terms of the strong modularity thesis of mind, or the Pleistocene environment of evolutionary adaptedness, but I think the push for evolutionary explanations of our psychology is a useful one.My main issues were with style/structure. Pinker covers a huge range of material in a fairly haphazard fashion, with only minimal use of subheadings etc. to mark out where we are in his larger argument. Some chapters were over 100 pages and felt like they were filled with unnecessary detail. Much of it was interesting in its own right (such as the formal structural rules of music), but did nothing to further his view. Instead of a directed argument, it felt more like a meander across a landscape of neuroscience, psychology, behavioural ecology, anthropology, musicology . . . any tangent that seemed interesting.I also found the title misleading - instead of finding out HOW the mind works, in most cases were were examining WHY the mind works - the possible evolutionary puzzles that could have led to particular aspects of our behaviour. In most instances, the exact mechanisms of cognition were left aside, which was disappointing. If he really wants to make the case that we have specialised modules for particular aspects of cognition, I think more attention needed to be paid to how these might function, not just why they could have been adaptive.Lots of interesting ideas (I loved finding out exactly how Magic Eye illusions trick our brains, and how disgust functions), but you definitely have to work hard to uncover them.

My 3-star rating of this book doesn't reflect so much on the book, as my mind-set while I read it. I didn't get a whole lot out of the book and wasn't in the right mood to get much out of it. Add to that the extreme length of it (22 hours in audiobook format), and it wasn't that great for me. I started listening to it at 1X speed, increased to 1.25, then eventually just wanted to finish the thing so I could move onto something else so I listened to the last half of it at 2X speed, not paying attention well and not comprehending much.One positive take-away that I did have was a recurring theme in any book that talks about the brain/mind: Computers and Artificial intelligence are almost always mentioned. I have several theories as to why this is a near-universal thing, but my favorite is that it wasn't until the computer boom in the 50's, 60's, and 70's when some really brilliant mathematicians and scientists wanted to create computers and robotics that would mimic human behavior and thought, essentially Artificial Intellience. But in order to create a computer program that mimicked what the human brain and mind were capable of, it sparked the natural question of what exactly does the human brain and mind do?! It's like reverse engineering a problem, and in an attempt to copy our brain, scientists spent ever-increasing amounts of resources into a study into how and what makes our brains tick. Hence, most of the books I've read attempting to unlock the inner workings of our brain will mention (or even devote chapters to) artificial intelligence, robotics, and smart men like Pascal, Alan Turing, and Isaac Asimov.I hope I can re-read this someday when I can get more out of it.

In a nutshell, Pinker explains how the mind works. Certainly that is a bold statement, so to clarify, Pinker summarizes a body of evidence from cognitive neuroscience, psychology, evolutionary biology, and evolutionary psychology that pertain to how our mind functions. He is a strong proponent of the computational theory of mind, and provides a series of strong arguments to support that position within the study of human cognition. He explains quite a bit including many details of how the visual system works and also its relation to the visual arts, the auditory system and its relation to our appreciation of music, how our emotions may not be so irrational after all, and ultimately how the way we see, think, and feel largely result from a battle between competing mental modules that evolved through natural selection to serve specialized purposes. He also reminds the reader that not all products of culture are evolutionary adaptations, and so Pinker also examines some that are likely to be adaptations (and some that are likely not) and also how they pertain to how our mind works. Pinker also discusses some of the differences between men and women (and between other family members), and that because of the different genetic investments of each, evolution has created unique emotions for each sex pertaining to offspring, infidelity, and other human affairs (no pun intended). My edition was 565 pages, and every page was worth reading. While a lot of it wasn't new information to me as I've dabbled in a few of the subjects before, Pinker did a great job keeping me engaged regardless. A good book indeed.

This is an interesting book that - as those who skip the title page may be surprised to learn - describes to us laymen how the mind works. Pinker uses an evolutionary framework to explain not only the functions of the brain but the reasoning for why it works in the way it does. Topics range from the physical to the intellectual to the emotional activities of the brain, although I thought he didn't do a great job exploring the links between each.Evolutionary psychology has much to teach us about the way humans work and how we got to where we are now, but the deeper thinker will find it unsatisfying. It leaves unanswered some important questions about the human condition because it sees no reason to pose them in the first place. Yes, the concept of natural selection has some interesting things to say about the phenomenon of love, but we must move beyond that to fully grasp what it means for the individual. (Please note that I am not arguing there must be something else to these profound phenonena just because we humans want there to be, but rather because the subject aspects are sometimes more important than the objective.) How the Mind Works actually does much to demonstrate my point: his final chapter grapples with the meaning of life, and but I suspect most readers put it down thinking there is something more. Evolutionary psychology is not wrong, but it's not the full story either.That said, this is an engaging and readable book that I recommend. I feel smarter having read it

Pinker's "How the Mind Works" revolves around two central themes -- the computational theory of mind and natural selection. In the beginning, he devotes a lot of time and energy to shooting down other theories, which would be fine if he wasn't such a jerk about it. Most of his targets don't really seem to merit all that much energy, and his criticisms become simply a showcase for academic aggression, like a prizefighter working over some random guy picked up off the street. Strangely, he seems to devote more time and energy to showing why others are wrong than to convincing the reader why the theories he believes in are right. After about 200 pages he settles down a little and actually starts getting into some practical discussions of how the mind works. He addresses topics like vision, emotions, and relations with other people. At times, I was fascinated, for paragraphs or even pages. But Pinker's ambition is a little too grand, he's set himself too large a project, and the book grows thin in places. He gets diverted pretty easily, and those diversions rarely worked for me. A grand example of this is his theory on the development of food-related religious laws, which were apparently intended to keep people from fraternizing with neighboring groups. The book did engage me at times -- I found myself arguing with him more than once -- and he raises some provocative ideas here and there, but part of the problem with him calling so much attention to incorrect theories at the beginning of the book is that this serves as a reminder that most theories eventually get brought down.

I have to give this book 5 stars for it is certainly the most painfully enlightening book I have ever read.It takes me like 4 months to get through, very slowly. There is nothing obscure about Steven Pinker's explanation about the human mind, though it could take very long to vaguely piece all the information together. He thinks about everything and applied modern psychology, evolutionary psychology, computational theory of the mind to explain it. The information in this book is massive. You can find all the reasonable explanation of how human works in this book : the visual system, the linguistic system, emotions, family values, art, music,....almost everything. There are so many things that we take for granted, but it is such a difficult engineering problem for the mind to work that way. Now I can understand why our intellects could sometimes relinquish its power to our emotions, or why there is visual illusion, or the cognitive niche:social living, color-seeing, 3D-seeing, language-using, hand-using,.... that gives rise to human intellects (according to S.P), so on and so forth.What is great about reading is that you can thinking other people's thought. What is great about thinking is once you do it you cannot unthink it. I feel glad I have tried to finish this book, because now I come to see the world with much more scientific and rigorous view. Needless to say, I will have to read it few more times to grasp it fully. I wish to learn it well enough so I can see the faults in his reasoning. But so far, I feel happily though vaguely enlightened.

I know the book has definite shortcomings. For one, it is mostly second and third hand information, that is, he relates different experiments and different theories that he agrees with and tries less (thought he does try) to bring diverging viewpoints into the discussion. Secondly, the book is indebted to Richard Dawkins' The Selfish Gene from which he draws most of his conclusions in evolutionary genetics and the relevant experiments which make up half of the book (the second half). And finally, the book betrays its age, as current advances in computer pattern recognition are way beyond the limits of what he envisaged back in 1997.However, the book is based on something else which is, I think, Pinker's most important contribution. This is the computational theory of mind, which he painstakingly tries to explain, along with the concepts associated with computation. Less generally accepted, but very stimulating for me, were the discussions on evolutionary psychology and (to a lesser extent) evolutionary development. The data to support these claims are less than concrete and draw different conclusions in different theoretical frameworks, but to me the conclusions are satisfying answers (so you can say that this is mysticism I can relate to) and hold the promise of future discoveries which can either confirm them or make changes to them.

Discovering this book for me is like finding a bible I can believe in. In a sense it is a collection of books after all. Each chapter can stand alone, and the whole is more than an sum of its parts. Pinker is an evolutionary psychologist, linguist, cognitive scientist etc. His marvelous facility with language and his skill at pulling his research together into coherent, even humorous and lively explanations - though often hammered home at excessive length, but who dares to be his editor??? - make How the Mind Works a treat for my brain, a one that is usually starved for information, insight and delight at this level of understanding, evolution and sophistication. Parralax, geons, prisoner's dilemma, cognitive dissonance, repleteness: words and concepts such as these that I find extremely tasty fill the book. I also have Pinker's "The Better Angels of Our Nature" both from the library. After renewing twice, both are due tomorrow. I got so hung up on working through the chapter called "Thinking Machines" that I made very slow progress - like trying to struggle though Genesis. In the interest of speed I skipped to another "book" and discovered "Family Values." I highly recommend that if you are not a scientist, you read this chapter first. It has the sexier passages. That will reel you in to concentrate on the more challenging investigations. My favorite typo is on the bottom of page 361 (1997 first edition): ...azlso!

Like the two other books of Pinker's I've read, The Blank Slate and The Stuff of Thought, this one is just as excellently written, entertaining, and profound. He gracefully takes complex topics and explains them with thoroughness and understandability without dumbing them down.I wasn't aware to the extent that this work would deal with evolutionary psychology, however. I know that Pinker is a firm advocate of the stance, and I share his position, but I'm already well acquainted with most of the research done in support of the field. Pinker elucidates all of it elegantly, and I don't have any criticisms regarding any of his explanations, but it's just that most of it was old news to me. I was hoping that more of the book would deal directly with the visual system and the explanation and implications of the computational theory of mind, which took up only the first few sections of the book. He does seem a bit too hastily dismissive of criticisms of the computational theory, too, which could have been taken more seriously and been given more space. There's also an odd lack of coverage given to consciousness research, which was puzzling.Anyway, anyone that's read and enjoyed Pinker's other books would probably like this one, too. This is also a great as start as any for an introduction to the thinking behind evolutionary psychology.

When I began the book, he said he would prove that the brain is an evolved organ relies on a lot of very specialized processing equipment. I already believed the former, and I believed that there were some instances of the latter.I definitely raised my estimate after reading his book. But nudging a numeric estimate isn't exactly paradigm shifting for me.On the other hand, he throws in quotes, and experiments, and a lot of philosophic and linguistic arguments. Who thought philosophy had anything to offer? I always thought it was the anti-science, always chasing the biggest questions with no hope of grasping them, never bothering with answerable issues. He makes pretty good use of it! And jokes. He throws in a lot of great, quotable jokes.And he thinks about EVERYTHING, applying his theory to it. So, a lot of that is rushed, or weak, but all of it is interesting and thought provoking.Of course evolutionary psychology theories are hard to test and easy to offer. That may not be great science, but we know that's where the answers must lie. If we evolved then our brains and minds evolved too.It is over long. Although I loved reading it, eventually I tired and reached for something lighter. When I got back to it, I was so glad. But a few pages later, I was done. Turns out, about the last 30% of my ebook was footnotes and citations.

This approachable and highly informative book on the mind and its development through the eyes and mind of Steven Pinker was worth the effort on so many levels. His wide reaching analysis and humor made the very specific topics and material radiate with clarity. This book was purchased in 1998 by me at the Legion of Honour in San Francisco, California and was interestly showcased at the retrospective the museum had up on the artwork of Francis Bacon. Very fitting material for reading next to the psychologically challenging work of Bacon if you are to ask me!This book's breadth of material can be best summoned up by the author himself:'This book is {about how} the mind owes it power to its syntactic, compositional, {and} combinatorial abilities (Chapter 2). Our complicated ideas are built out of simpler ones, and the meaning of the whole is determined by the meaning of the parts and the meaning of the relations that connect them: part-of-a-whole, example-of-a category, thing-at-a place, actor-exerting-force, cause-of-an-effect, mind-holding-a-belief,...'If the mind is of interest to you from the vantage point of a pre eminent professor of psychology and director of the Center for Cognitive Neuroscience at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology should be read with careful consideration and an open perspective.

I appreciate that Pinker doesn't pretend that his exploration and analysis of the brain doesn't really explain consciousness, self-awareness, and that he admits that nobody has explained them, even if they claim to. So right away, I get that he gets it's a tough problem, and it's too easy to say consciousness doesn't exist.It does.The early chapters, then, are pretty interesting. So were the later chapters, but Pinker seemed to forget what his book was about when he got into the chapter about families and sexual behavior. Interesting, but too far away from how the brain works. And really long.Then I liked the last chapter again, especially the ending. If philosophers for millennia haven't been able to reconcile self-awareness with meat and electrical impulses, maybe it's not the problem is unsolvable, but only that our brains aren't made to think like that. We evolved to do what we do well, and things that are visual (for instance, geometry, our understanding of time) are right up our alley. Maybe, just like most people can't really imagine 4 dimensions the way they are, because our brains just aren't made for it, so we can't really understand consciousness. I'll keep looking, but maybe that's correct, too.

How the Mind Works is an introductory book to the theories of the mind advocated by Pinker. Two major parts can be identified. First a computational theory of the mind is laid out. Pinker explains how the mind can be understood as being composed of computational modules that correspond to physical structures in the brain. In the early development, an individual learns to use these modules for their intended tasks such as recognizing speech, seeing in 3D using stereoscopic vision and so on. The crown jewel is chapter 4 “The Mind’s Eye”, a rigorous treatment on how the mind solves very complex vision problems. People who do not have stereoscopic vision, such as myself, may find this a bit of a discouraging and confusing read. The latter half of the book discusses to a large extent behavioral and social issues and how these can be understood from the evolutionary point of view as well as from the computational and modular model of the mind. The ideas and arguments are interesting and entertaining, but the rigor is not comparable to the first half. I recommend the second half as an easy reading about an evolutionary understanding of behavior. Read the first part if you are up for a somewhat detailed exposition of the computational theory of the mind.

I loved the book! At times I thought I was listening to the manual for life. The book is about the evolution of the mind and very convincingly explains why we do / think most of what we do. Parts of the book were way over my head, but I listened anyway. I should have posted my review of each chapter as I completed it. There are so many gems in the book that I'll keep with me for ever.A couple of examples. The description of the evolution of the eyes and how stereo vision was rather complex, but then I attended Open Doors Toronto and at the Campbell House there was an exhibit of stereograms. The coincidence was astounding and really enhanced my appreciation of the exhibit.The other one that will stick with me was the simple ritual of dating. It goes something like this.... dates consist of food, entertainment and affection. At the beginning of a relationship, there is more entertainment than affection, but there is food. As the relationship gets more serious, the affection becomes the entertainment, but there is always food. The descriptions of how the mind processes music was way over my head. I'm sure that those who have a music knowledge would better understand that chapter.I loved the book and am glad I listened to it. I may listen to it again....

Definitely a good and interesting book, but I liked "The Blank Slate" a lot better. Having just read (listened to) Dawkins' "The Selfish Gene" right before this one, I got to see just how much of Dawkin's book is rehashed in Pinker's. That's fine, of course, as a solid understanding of the ideas of Dawkins (and Darwin, et al) are needed to understand Pinker's elaborations from a more psychological and sociological level. There were some very interesting sections of the book, most notably the part about vision and the brain, including the explanation of how our minds interpret and allow us to see autostereograms. I also liked the section on religion, and the end of the book regarding the questions that we do not yet have answers to. Other parts of the book were a little less interesting (especially if you already have a grasp on "The Selfish Gene"), and at least one part was hilariously boring (music and sound).The book is obviously a little dated, especially with all the advancements in this area since the time the book was written, but this was addressed in the Afterword, and I am sure also in some of his more recent books. But all in all, this was and interesting and mostly satisfying read.

A very thorough and well-written book regarding the specific importance and evolutionary purpose of the human brain, presented via the engaging and intelligent authorship of Steven Pinker - who's book 'The Better Angels of Our Nature' (about the decline of violence in human society) is one of the best books I have ever read.This book examines a range of aspects of the human mind, providing scientific explanation of the nuts and bolts of how these processes work biologically, and then the importance of these abilities are discussed in the context of evolutionary biology and sociology to provide insight into just how important these adaptations are. Language, stereoscopic vision, altruism, music, social constructs, emotion, imagination and pleasure-seeking are all discussed with use of numerous illustrative examples and quotes (I turned over so many page corners with important insights on, I forget which of the numerous were most impactful!) at a level that cleverly doesn't alienate the non-expert nor patronise/bore the scientifically well-educated such as myself.I would recommend this to anyone wanting to read about the importance of the human brain in how we have evolved to become the dominant species in the current world.

This is a huge book which cannot be skimmed. The basic idea is computational theory of mind rather than neurons, synapse, and chemical reactions. I found the computational sections interesting but really bogged down in the parts where he illustrates his theories on mind biology in terms of natural selection as reserved in the genes rather than any learned or taught via psychological response. "The mind is a neural computer, fitted by natural selection with combinatorial algorithms for causal and probalistic reasoning about plants, animals, objects, and people. It is driven by goal states that served biological fitness in ancestral environments, such as food, sex, safety, parenthood, friendship, status, and knowledge." p.524 What matters most is "mechanism that brings about effects that would increase the number of copies of the genes building the nechanism in the environment in which we evolved." p.526The cultural references were age appropriate for a boomer and will date this book for younger audiences and in the near future. For example, Bob Dylan, "When you got nothing, you got nothing to lose."

Brilliant book. I can't recommend it enough. Lucid and readable. The computational theory of the mind is just great. It makes so much sense, and is much better than some of the other views of how it works, e.g. what I see as the false dichotomy between reason and emotion. From why people do silly things, to a fascinating chapter on how the mind sees. He often describes some of the different views, and then tells us which he prefers, all backed up with excellent evidence. I get so tired of evolutionary evangelists and fundamentalists (e.g. that annoying pillock Dawkins), and when Pinker introduces his view of evolution it's well thought out, refreshing and more to the point realistic, and so is a great backdrop to some of his theories. He does waver towards the end of the book, coming out with less than convincing arguments, and it seems that he may not have studied some of the areas so closely, but then maybe these are more difficult to test in isolated lab situations. Took me a long while to read as the stuff Pinker comes out with requires thought and discussion down the pub. However absolutely worth the effort.

It's been said by many others that Pinker writes about complex subjects in a very accessible way, and this book is no exception. His descriptions mix scientific elegance and precision with down-to-earth metaphors and examples from daily life. I've found myself thinking about many of the concepts he illustrates in the context of my own life; as an example, he explains that experiments with infants have shown their capacity to recognize separate objects and their innate sense of how the world works. In the experiment, two dolls are shown to the infant, then hidden by a screen; the experimenter secretly moves one of the dolls out of the baby's field of vision, then removes the screen. The baby will stare, recognizing that it does not make sense for only one doll to be visible. When I was playing with a friend's baby the other day, I tried a modified version of this myself, and it seemed to keep her attention, which I thought was pretty cool.This is just one example of the numerous fascinating illustrations of the mind's structure and relation to the world, explained in language that informs without overwhelming - if you're looking for a flood of jargon, look elsewhere.

A good book for many new facts, ideas and theories, but jumpy and without radical new conclusions. The title of the book is a misnomer. The author frequently gets excited about explaining evolution, whether in organs, thoughts or behaviours. He tries to justify these wanderings by vaguely linking to the mind but if there is any central theme in the book, it is less related to the workings of the mind than justifications of evolutionary theories.That said, the book's rich details are exciting for anyone with patience and desire to learn. The book does get difficult for non-experts in parts (particularly the section on eye), but the breadth of the topics covered is still fascinating and shows the efforts put in by the author. While the author refrains from taking strong assertive stands (so are minds automatons with all experiences an illusion? something the author tries to support indirectly without taking a firm stand), the author - like most critics - has more fun poking holes in alternate theories including religious or Freudian varieties.

This book is by no means bad. In fact it is very good at what it does, which is reduce life and consciousness to bits of junk (my interpretation). If you want to feel insignificant, read this book ... by the end you will feel as important as a brick. Please don't think that this makes this book any less impressive ... it is an awesome collection of state of the art research into human consciousness, neural networking, artificial intelligence, and thought. If you are able to learn the brain/mind to the point of striping it of all emotion (in my opinion, taking the "life" out of life) without feeling reduced, then this is your new favorite book ... I, on the other hand, want to forget what little I was able to understand from this opus. I want to experience life, not compute it.

This book first chapters were very easy and nice to go through, but there are a few chapter somewhere in the first half of the book that were not so interesting to me. I don't know exactly what happened but getting through these few chapters took me months. Then the book became once again pleasant and inteligible and went like this to the end.My highlights are on:A few pages dedicated on how mathematical concepts and thoughts are processed in our brains.The discussion about the processes that control our emotions and why they evolved to be the way they are.Despite a few boring chapters the book is very valuble to everybody who want to build up a strong scientific background. Most of the time the language is very accessible, and I believe, Pinker managed very well to put things on a simple language without oversimplify and distort meaning (this is very commmon in books on modern physics and related topics).

Discovery Channel used to have Shark Week. PBS Nova should have a full month on "How the Mind Works" base on Steven Pinker's theories. While it was interesting to read, it was also frustrating to finish because the subject just got draining after a while. Some of his examples, like family incest, almost became unbearable to read. I really wanted to skip that part because it seemed like Pinker went on for over an hour on incest. It just seemed like that they author was being infatuated on incest and I still don't understand how the mind works on this disgusting sexual taboo. This book is hard to understand because there are so many examples that you will be overwhelm and after a while none of it makes any sense. I still don't understand at what I read. There are far better books out there on this subject, like "The Mind and the Brain". That book has a better structure and course of plan to tell you what you need to know.

For the first five chapters Pinker employes a sometimes over technical and hard to follow (the biology of the eye, how cameras work, 90's computer tech, etc) explanation of how and why the mind might have evolved via natural selection. His attack on "psychological correctness" is nice. The second half of the book is much more interesting as it ventures into human nature, parent child conflict, gender differences, and more. If you are looking for an explanation for various neurosis or a self-help manual, this is not the book for you. If you're interested in evolution and biology, and nice little attacks on academia, you'll probably enjoy this one. Three stars for the first half, four for the second half. *EDIT* I changed my review from 3 stars to 4 because I got into a debate about evolutionary psychology shortly after finishing this book and found that I had a much larger tool box at my disposal.

In ‘How the Mind Works’ Steven Pinker (Harvard professor of psychology) looks at various aspects of the brain, how it evolved, how it develops from infant to adult and a few theories about how it works. Pinker is a proponent of the ‘computational theory of mind’ which proposes that the brain acts in a step by step fashion, manipulating symbols in order to arrive at an output. The first few chapters are a bit of a chore as Pinker jumps from topic to topic in such a dizzying scattershot of distantly related topics that one struggles to grasp the point of the discussion. Eventually he settles down and begins to lay out his ideas in way that proceeds logically and the book markedly improves. Overall the book is ok, though I’d point out that there are more current books on the topic available (this one was written in 1997) and ones that are better written.

A bit too ambitious. Pinker displays all his wonted amiability and accessibility, both of which are sorely needed in a book (partly) on evolutionary psychology. No amounts of either can sustain a book of this bulk, however. His cocktail-party style is singularly ill-suited to the sheer mass of material he tries to address: no number of witty one-liners can adequately handle (sometimes simultaneous) discussions of religion, evolution, ethics, sexual politics, biology and psychology (among others), but that's what Pinker tries to do. I never felt that I got a solid grip on one area before he zipped off to the next. That's a shame, because his clear and readable style seemed to be the perfect medium for making these complex understandable. So much potential- actually, too much potential.

Very, very, very detailed insight of what the mind is and how and (for the most part) why we behave the way we do.In addition to presenting both sides of the argument before stating his point in as concise a manner as possible, Pinker also makes sure to include plenty of examples and analogies (ranging from The Twilight Zone to Monty Python) which turn what could have been a terribly droll blah-fest into a fun, easily-comprehensible presentation of how the mind works.FYI, the book clocks in at a whopping 565 page of small, 12-point font text - not including the 95 pages of the appendix at the end of the book - so if you're seeking a light read I suggest looking elsewhere. Otherwise, if the subject matter interests you and you have the time and patience, by all means go for it - it'll give you plenty of food for thought.

Fascinating book, and a good follow-up to Pinker's "The Language Instinct". Strongly based on two concepts, the "computational theory of mind" and natural selection. Doesn't get very deeply into brain chemistry but focuses on the why we do what we do. It may occasionally be accused of beating a concept to death - though not blatantly so, and the conversational writing style compensates for this quite well.I do wonder how some of the conclusions would change based on technologies, particularly regarding social networking, that have surged in popularity since 2009 when the book was released, FMRI advancements and advancements in artificial intelligence - and in fact, part of the afterward does acknowledge this possibility. A very thorough investigation of the topic and certainly worth the time if you want to better understand yourself, and those around you.

I would give this book 3.5 stars. Dr. Pinker does a good job providing the evolutionary underpinnings to how the mind has evolved in its functionality and utility. He provides a lot of detail on myriad issues with the mind (e.g, how the mind the mind works similarly to a computational model). This book is a very dense read and I still came away not understanding as much as I expected, although the mind is very complex, which the author reinforces. At times, he gets very technical and complex in his descriptions on topics that I was not able to understand (how the mind deciphers the image of the visual autostereogram). However, I feel this is due to my own limitations more than anything else. I enjoyed his provocative questions and appreciated the nexus between evolution and the development of the mind.

Great book on what we know about how the mind works. Lots of conjecture in here, too, and it's sometimes hard to tell the difference between fact and supposition. And, as we know, even the facts tend to change in fields like this one as we learn more.The thing that irritates me the most about books like this is how much the atheists have to do their proselytizing. Too many, including Mr. Pinker, believe that because they know how something works it's obvious there can't be a being such as God. It's especially ludicrous because they know they're only scratching the tip of the iceberg, yet that little alone is apparently enough to make God irrelevant.Anyway, what he presents is done well and really helped me understand what we know about brain science and how our brain mechanics affect our behaviors.Really liked the book.

The book describes in detail how the natural selection turned human brain into a perfect machine to solve a number of required tasks, starting from simple functionality of body to survive and finishing with complex adaptation inside family and community. Computational options of the brain ( math, language, etc.) and activity of emotions (disgust, fear, happiness, etc) are outlined deeply. In my opinion, the best part of the book is the last chapter characterizing the roles of art, music, literature and humor. The main hypothesis suggests that these activities are just brain errors (“bugs”), however rather pleasant and sometimes useful. Notably, the book also provides hundreds of references and it is easy to find additional information about any interesting topic. I’ll just finish with a citation: “Our mental life is a noisy parliament of competing factions”.

Possibly a bit out of date (I remember noticing that he cited a study about rats consuming addictive substances if they were freely available which has since been shown to be mostly because they were put in isolated cages and not because animals will inherently choose to be blissed out if given the choice), but it did have some interesting stuff in it. A little hard to read at times because of the way in which he uses language (very brusque) and they way he talks about human behavior as if the way we evolved to do things is the "right" way (while he does have a disclaimer about this saying that he's not making moral judgments before he starts doing it, it's very hard to read it differently from how it's written).The book has several asides which are somewhat interesting in and of themselves but seem to somewhat distract from the main purpose of the book.

As always in the case of Pinker's books, this has been a long, instructive journey. I've learned a lot of things about the manner in which the brain works, which is a great part to read when one feels down - it turns out people, even in their first months of life, are quite amazing creatures. Also, the aspects about why we behave the way we do towards other people, about why we like art and why we fear certain things are definitely revealing and give great insight into human nature.However, this book did not blow my mind exactly the way The blank slate and Better angels of our nature did, I am not sure why. Maybe because I was already aware of most of the information from other sources? Or because I felt it was a lot more technical than the others. Either way, do not be discouraged, but check it out - there's something in it for anyone with a healthy curiosity.

Pinker writes well, that is for sure. I loved his other books (The Language Instinct and Blank Slate). But somehow I am really struggling to get through this one.The anecdotes and metaphors are mildly interesting. There are also a few interesting scientific tidbits here and there. But at 80-100 pages a piece, the chapters are just too long. On top of that, if you have read The Language Instinct or Thinking, Fast and Slow (Daniel Kahneman), there's very little new here.This book is also much more from the perspective of psychology than it is from biology or neurology. If you are interested in how the brain works, as I am, this book is not for you. If, however, you are interested in finding some better metaphors for thinking about thought, this might be interesting to you. As for me, it's 2 stars.

This book is written in a very engaging manner that is interesting and accessible for both the scientist and lay person. I felt the first half of the book was stronger, more salient, and supported with biological evidence than the second half, but overall Pinker succeeds in presenting a broad subject with clarity. His explanations of AI, the development of the eye and its ability to process images, and introductions to both computational and evolutionary aspects of neuroscience were very well done and rooted in research. However, as the book progresses, Pinker relies more on philosophy, loosely connected theories, and does not draw any new or striking conclusions. Still, I found the book to be enjoyable and informative.

This book explains how the mind works using the computacional theory of mind and evolutionary psychology.The author uses popular language and examples to explain difficult concepts, but I think the conceptual framwork needs to be more detailed, because the theory used is one among lots of other, and Pinker is some kind of fuzzy with the rest of the theories.The major problem, in my point of view, it is the computacional theory of mind itself, and your use of the actual computers to try explain how the human mind works. It can explain how we use logic and memory, but not how we interact with the world, with other humans, or with ethical and moral problems.[Based on Brazilian Portuguese Edition:]

A compelling argument regarding how the mind works that dispels blank slate notions by presenting the evolutionary basis for and purpose of our current mental faculties--that is, we evolved to solve certain problems, and our minds evolved to make certain inferences and perform certain functions, consistent with that path. A reader without a strong science background might have some trouble with the technical vagaries of the evolution of vision and Pinker's "computational theory of mind", but surviving those chapters pays off in the end. Grand in scope--everything from vision to thought process to sibling rivalry to belief in the supernatural is analyzed. What emerges is both evocative and inspiring.

On the top of my shoulders sits a box made of bone. Within that box is a greyish organ with the texture of jelly, the size of a melon (canteloupe, not water) that controls pretty much everything that I do. Billions of microscopic connections allow me to generate thoughts, process input, communicate, control posture and interpret data with a speed that is not matched by the fastest and biggest computers we have yet invented. The brain is a phenomenon and should be a thing of constant marvel but we take it for granted as long as it does what we expect. Steven Pinker has written a fabulous, dense book to try and generate a level of knowledge about the Mind that increases the sense of wonder whilst explaining some of the processes involved.

This book was tough to rate, because where it's good, it's brilliant, but there is a lot of bad. I came to this book hoping to learn about the science of thought. While there was valuable science in this book, much of it was taken up with polemical railing against straw man opponents--rabid anti-evolutionist academics, deluded feminists--who in my experience are both rarer and wiser than Pinker portrays them. I chose to read a book on science, because I already accept the scientific worldview. I do not need to spend huge portions of the book reading about basic evolutionary science, much less in the form of an angry tirade. Thank you, Dr. Pinker, for your book. I highly valued the information within it, but please, next time, tone down the rhetoric.

The first half of the book was pretty mediocre as the author tried to explain how various aspects of human nature resulted from natural selection from the obvious to the controversial. Seemed to be a 3-star book until the last third where it really became interesting because he addressed questions I had often wondered about. In particular, the relation of evolution to music, art, prestige, altruism and other things that don't seem to be part of the "survival of the fittest" scene. He had interesting observations and I don't think all of his answers were correct but I don't think anyone has all the right answers in explaining human nature. Also, interesting information on sex, mating, male and female from a materialistic view.

A very good book that doesn't really solve many of the questions that you may have before reading it, and perhaps hope to solve by reading it, but instead gives many new points ofview, as well as a wealth of data and insights for you to try and figure out answers for yourself, if that is even possible. The focus on experiment results, as well as the chapter dedicated on how toddlers perceive the world around them is specially interesting, as well as the one focusing on human inter-relationships.Would recommend reading this, but also, be prepared to want to read other points of view on the subject. Definitely, the idea of the book is for you to open your mind to new ideas, not to embrace any idea that you might think this book could contain, and declare all your doubts quenched.

Pinker reviews the current research and theories on the workings of the human mind. He explains current theories on the evolutionary basis of vision, hearing, emotions and common sense physics, psychology and morality. He also explores the evolutionary basis of non-adaptive behaviors including listening to music and watching movies.His explanations are lucid and well-written and this book is a great pleasure to read. However, in the very last section, Pinker seems to completely lose his nerve and, in a short passage with no science and a small amount of shaky philosophy, Pinker announces that the hardest problems of the human mind, like sentience, are beyond the grasp of science and the human intellect. It's a disappointing ending to an otherwise excellent book.

Quality compendium on all things of the mind. The author substitutes subject depth for breadth, which works rather well. The first half lays out the challenges and wonder of the brain. It felt like good source material if you were going to program AI. The second half was more a generalised on the topic of human misconceptions and brain tricks.The material and references felt slightly dated, mainly around those directed at computers and their march towards better replication of aspects of humans.If you've haven't read any psychological books before, this is the perfect place to start. If you have, then there is probably not enough niche subject matter analysis.Overall: 4 stars for quality of research and delivery, but could have been shorter and punchier.

How the Mind Works is a great book, one that raises questions along with answering them. In its structure it is split into 8 distinct chapters and split further into a number of sub-chapters. The book talks of how the mind works and provides insight into the Evolutionary reasons of why. This book doesn't pull punches with how it views feminism and courtship and all of that stuff. In general, I enjoy books that make me think and expose unflattering truths about humanity, and this book also does both.All in all, I could read this again and again if I didn't have other books to read. Perhaps I will read it again in 10 years. It might be pretty dated by then, but human nature doesn't change overnight and a lot of these observations will still be accurate 10 years from now.

There's a lot of fascinating information in this book, but the writing is a little dense and to be honest, boring. As one example, the long drawn out explanation of how a computer would figure out who a person's uncle is went on and on until I wanted to throw the book out of the window. Often the only purpose of these over-explanations seems to be to be able to say at the end of it all, 'and gosh, our brain just does that, better, and in a fraction of the time.' which is amazing, but still. The part about babies and what they are capable of discerning at just a few months old was really interesting. In fact, all of the content was generally interesting. I just with there was a condensed version available.

Starts as a book about the computational theory of mind and quickly transitions towards the evolutionary theories of psychology (I was hoping for more of the former). I have heard some talk about the "Pinker fallacy", such as those statistical errors committed in "the better angels of our nature", and I struggled to spot as much here. Perhaps Pinker is in safer territory in this realm of psychology vs social sciences. The writings about art, music, family values, religion etc were insightful but some things are better to be experienced and lived than to be analyzed, a paragraph about a piece of art can never compare of the piece itself, perhaps this book will inspire me to get my a** to an art museum or the like. All in all an enjoyable read and I would recommend.
