But if our minds are part of nature, that is to be expected, even welcomed. The natural world evokes our awe by the specialized designs of its creatures and their parts. We don’t poke fun at the eagle for its clumsiness on the ground or fret that the eye is not very good at hearing, because we know that a design can excel at one challenge only by compromising at others. Our bafflement at the mysteries of the ages may have been the price we paid for a combinatorial mind that opened up a world of words and sentences, of theories and equations, of poems and melodies, of jokes and stories, the very things that make a mind worth having.

Steven Pinker at his best. While some of his other books dive deeper into some specific areas touched on in this book, "How the Mind Works" covers a lot ground while clearly articulating Pinker's take on the computation theory of mind and how it ties into evolutionary psychology. He describes many ways we humans use our brains to form what we call our mind, how more fundamental mental processes might have been cobbled together to help us do what we do, and examines dozens of facets of the mind along with how and why we may have come to possess these mental "modules" in the forms we do. He presents a fascinating and convincing argument for his thesis and I highly recommend this book to anyone interesting in thinking more about how we think. One of my favorite books by Pinker.

One of my all-time favourites. This book heavily influenced me, the way I thought and analysed the world, skepticism about religion, understanding human behaviour etc etc.Pinker is a fantastic science writer. I was told that I should have read The Language Instinct first, but I picked this book up using my 'randomly open a book at the book-store and see if you can read it for more than 10 minutes' strategy of choosing books when I was a kid and I didn't regret it.The first chapter on how the eye works is complicated, and almost put me off reading later chapters. If you can get through that you'll much enjoy the rest of the book. Well worth it.

How The Mind Works is a national best seller. It is a book portraying the elegance of the human mind. It is a collection of Pinker’s hard work and his analyses of human behavior. He portrayed human beings and human minds as the ultimate being and I didn’t quite agree with that concept. But besides that, his ideas were revolutionary and challenging to understand. The title is somewhat misleading. It is not all about the brain. This book contains more than 600 pages, but more than 30 percent of the contents are about the evolution of human behaviors. I learned way too much to be able to write them all on this book review. I will be done with the book shortly.

Alternately technically impenetrable and grossly over-simplified, Pinker nevertheless delivers interesting insights into human behavior. Don't be confused, this book is about how the "mind" works, not the brain. Pinker tackles diverse mental functions from stereo vision to emotions to social interactions. His broad theory is that the way we think evolved as an aid to human survival, and that many behaviors we think of as "societal" are actually innate functions of the mind. Some of his theories, especially on gender roles and religion, are controversial but compellingly intuitive.This book left me thinking, to paraphrase The Big Lebowski: "You're not wrong, you're just an asshole."

One of the best books I've ever read.  A carefully narrated walk through the behavioral sciences reaching into the fields of neuroscience, computer science, psychology and genetics to explain our thinking and behaviour as a species.  Every page is painstakingly researched but presented in clear easy to follow language (well, most of the time).  Undoubtedly this book will change your mind on many aspects of psychology. Persevere to the second part of the book which is much less technical and much more interesting (the psychology of family, friends, sex, gender roles, religion, art, music, war, you name it!)

I found this to be very interesting yet very difficult to get through. This is in no way a "light" read, even the book feels heavier than it should. I think that there were quite a few points where it would have been helpful if Pinker had either eliminated the complicated examples in favor of one that was easier to understand OR inserted any example into pages and pages of information. Don't expect to read this once and fully understand everything, if that's your goal plan on reading it multiple times. That is not to say that you can't take away quite a bit off of one careful reading, you can but it'll require lots of concentration.

This is the book I've been needing to read for so long now, ever since I started questioning ecerything I've been told, or better said after learning that the answers I had about life and us humans were actually poor excuses of an answer.This book is sharp, it's focused, well-balanced, and has humour, without it being in any way malitious to any other theories that have been proposed on the big questions we have in our minds: what and how does conscience work, what is moral, who is that "me" I feel, and where does it come from.The authour wanted for us to get outside the framing of our minds and acknowledging it for what it is: a marvelous result of natural selection.

Another of Pinker's awesome books. This book synthesizes and describes studies of the human mind. Academic disciplines such as biology, psychology, cognitize science, and the arts are categorized with examples of how knowledge of human capabilities has been built. Topics such as language and speech, visual phenomena, logic and reasoning, quantative measurement making, likes and dislikes, social science, art appreciation, and philosophy are covered. The vast range of topics, and Pinker's unique way of describing things, make this an awesome book for both educational and personal knowledge development.

It took me six months to get through this book. There are alot of ideas covered, so it seems fitting to go through it slowly. Plus, even in paperback, the tome is hefty and not suitable of commute-reading. I really appreciate the Notes and References at the back. I nearly abandoned the book after reading Chapter 2. I suspect there are concepts on computational thinking that I just am not familiar enough with to understand, but also Pinker took on a combative tone that was equally incomprehensible. Overall, however, the "big picture" Pinker presents is enlightening - well worth sticking it out to the end.

Another fascinating book by Steven Pinker. Well written - enjoyable and informative. Covers everything about how and why our mind developed and works the way it does. Mostly based on the Computational Theory of Mind with various additions. The books answers many questions such as why spacial metaphors are so natural to use, why eating certain foods is gross, how 3D Magic-Eye pictures work and why is falling in love leave us powerless and blind.I had problems understanding the explanations on what gives us consciousness and free will. And feel the chapter on why music is natural to us incomplete.So so much fun, would love to read it again.

*Whew this was a pretty long read, but surprisingly enough it held me to the very end.First this is a book based on evolution, so those with certain beliefs beware. The title is kind of a misnomer or at least it can be misinterpreted easily. Going in I read the title and thought, "Cool a book about how the different parts of the brain work." That's not what its about, its really is about How (and why from an evolutionary standpoint) the Mind Works.Interesting ideas on how we've evolved to enjoy music, go to war, hold reciprocity in such high regard, have gender-specific sexual preferences, and much much more.Definitely worth the week it took me to read this.

This book was a game changer for me. I recommend it to anyone interested in psychology. Pinker essentially lays out the (rather compelling) case for evolutionary psychology and the computational theory of mind. In the decade since the book was written, these ideas have become even more popular amongst psychologists. The "blank slate" approach is becoming increasingly rare among those who should know better. Soon enough, its only supporters will be the stubborn souls at your local Sociology department. Pinker's writing is extremely easy for the interested layman to follow. This is probably why 'How The Mind Works' was the quickest 800 page book I've ever read.

I've been reading a lot of books on evolutionary psychology lately and this was one of the best I've come across. Pinker is witty and clever as he reverse-engineers the mind in the scope of natural selection and he covers a lot of ground in 550 easy-reading pages. The book covers many topics including how your eyes work, the computational theory of the mind, self deception, kin altruism, sexual selection, the psychology of war and art and ultimately the concept of free will. The book itself is designed to get you to think and it does so in the most attractive ways (like lots of great references to pop culture and literature).

This book is an examination of how the mind works based on psychological experiments (a surprising number on children), anecdotes and the thoughts of a variety of writers. While the book presents a number of interesting ideas, they are more speculative than having any scientific basis. Strangely, Pinker frequently uses ideas from fiction to illustrate his arguments - It is noticeable how little psychology and other social sciences have contributed to an understanding the mind. Pinker frequently presents theories only to subsequently show their shortcomings.A disappointing book offering few insights.

There is so much fodder for thought in these pages that you can't help but like the book just for the intellectual stimulation. I didn't agree with it all. I was offended at times. I've read some of the vignettes/studies before. And yet, there was enough new material and innovative thought to be intriguing and keep me reading. I especially liked the information on attraction and relationships. In fact, the book gets better and better as it nears it's end. I doubt I will read more of Pinker's work because his expertise is in language and I'm much more interested in mathematics, but I found this a good read and will share it with friends.

Quite a brilliant manifestation of the Evolutionary Psychology field and Steven Pinker's vast intellect.That said, the narrative is not flowing easily, and sometimes, Pinker's harsh criticism of the opposite hypotheses overshadows his own arguments, which is irritating at times.

I am just starting this book and it seems to provide a very readable overview of the capacity of the human mind. As it relates to artificial intelligence, Pinker would argue that the human mind is sufficiently complicated that a digital recreation would be extremely challenging. He approaches the mind from an evolutionary perspective and explains how many important mental and phsysical functions were developed over time for survival. More later.

Too much focus on ev-psych; too many snarky comments against detractors of evolution and ev-psych; an entire chapter dedicated to convincing the reader of evolution by natural selection. Epistemological pessimism (bordering on nihilism). Would have preferred more focus on the computational aspects of the mind. The first couple of chapters are strong, and everything after that is spotty.First read in January 2009; date is set to 2011 because I reread it and wish to include it in my "read" count for this year.

Extraordinary book, both extremely informative and entertaining. There is a lot to think about in the book, and it made me even more fascinated by Pinker's work and the fields of computational theory of mind and evolutionary psychology. It can be a bit heavy at times, especially when he describes areas such as optics and the construction of neural networks with toy neurons. But i was so entranced that I listened to it twice, so I could really have a good grasp of the theories and the explanations in the book.

If you are going to write a book exposing flaws in other theories because the have no evidence, the first thing you should have is evidence that supports your position. This book was extremely frustrating to read, and I finally stopped reading about 2/3 of the was through. The author put forth a variety of arguments about the evolution of the mind, talked extensively about alternate hypotheses that he believed were flawed and the provided no evidence to support his ideas beyond that he was obviously correct. Maddening.

This is an excellent book. It is not about the physical processes of the brain, nor, at least directly, about why people think weird things (as I thought it might be). Instead, the author tries to explain how we got to thinking some of the ways we do based on what made these thinking algorithms useful to our early ancestors and how that plays out in today's world.There are a lot of complicated ideas in here, yet this book is reasonably easy to understand and a lot of fun to read. I highly recommend it to anybody who likes to think about thinking.

Steven Pinker does for neuroscience/psychology what Jared Diamond did for evolutionary natural history, Rachel Carson did for environmental biology, Stephen Hawking did for physics etc etc etc. "the" name in a popular rewrite of brain science, Pinker's work is not absolutely even/mind-enrapturing (the entire first chapter can just be taken from a Psych 101 textbook), but he captures enough novel material and writes with sufficient facility that the layman can grasp the concepts and learn considerable new topics

So, it took me months to complete this book, but sometimes other things in life get in the way I guess. Nevertheless, great read. It is a really dense book filled with fascinating information and research that if you take time to consider, and as I often do with this type of book, underline passages for further research, it will take you a while to get through in it's entirety. Enjoyed it tremendously and now have a list of other books he references that I want to look into. Well worth the time and effort.

A great book that argues—well—how the mind works, how its functioning is inextricably intertwined with our biological meat suits. It tries to make abstractions over brain processes, bringing in computing terms like daemons, and so forth. Quite good, quite a lot of information that's tightly packed. I have one problem with this book: the author doesn't go through enough lengths to delineate speculation from what is actually known; which makes it difficult for the reader to get a clear picture about the world.

Pinker's second masterpiece (after Language Instinct, which I have yet to read for lack of time). The human brain is easily the most complex structure in our bodies and also the most misunderstood. Pinker takes data from the past 3 or so decades and constructs a theory of thought which is remarkably fluent. He explains where our brains came from via evolution, and how they enable us to interact with the world around us. A technically difficult read, but well worth it in the end.

The theme of the book is "human mind as a naturally chosen neuro-computer". The book starts off with a detailed description of the computational model of the human mind, continues with a rather detailed discussion of human vision and then moves on to a rather schematic description of various aspects of human existence, such as emotions, kin relations, humor, religion etc., depicted as devices of natural selection.

This is an interesting read for anyone interested in an approachable book about cognitive psychology. I have seen Pinker lecture twice, once for The Blank Slate and just recently for The Stuff of Thought. He is amazingly eloquent and I find myself constantly checking to see when he will be coming to Seattle. Unfortunately my timing has been off on this book (I began reading it a week before beginning graduate school), but hopefully I can finish it during one of by school breaks.

This is great work by Steven Pinker, I think I picked the right first book of his to read. This book presents theories and insights into all aspects of the minds of us humans from many sources that are quite convincing. I take away a better understanding of myself and others after reading this book and that is something of the highest value in my opinion. Ignorance may be bliss, but I value understanding more, and "How the Mind Works" is fuel for the latter.

This book was very well done. While the subject material is complex, Pinker's writing style is quite clear and detailed. He also imbues his material with wit and humor, which saves it from becoming just another dry academic treatise on neurology. While it doesn't possess the detail of an actual academic course, How the Mind Works is a good source for a basic introduction into evolutionary psychology and the computational theory of mind.

How the Mind Works describes what the mind is and how it evolved -- discussing everything from how we see and why we laugh. This book is enlightening and interesting. Dispels the nurture or nature myths and why it isn't an either/or proposition. Pinker calls it reverse-engineering the mind (and/or the brain). The insights and examples are from all areas of science making it incredibly fascinating and convincing.

My ratings of books on Goodreads are solely a crude ranking of their utility to me, and not an evaluation of literary merit, entertainment value, social importance, humor, insightfulness, scientific accuracy, creative vigor, suspensefulness of plot, depth of characters, vitality of theme, excitement of climax, satisfaction of ending, or any other combination of dimensions of value which we are expected to boil down through some fabulous alchemy into a single digit.

Again as with his another book "The Blank Slate" you need to soldier on through first several chapters full of filosophizing until you reach your ultimate destination - a wealth of eye-opening, thought-provoking and simply mind-boggling facts, experiments and conjectures on brain, conscience, society and what it is to be a human, collected from all over the world and from all walks of life. A sheer feast of ideas and revelations!
